Again, for longer missions maybe there will be another type of the trunk - with proper solar panels (and maybe fuel cells).

Very possible. I would imagine they want to make sure 7 people have enough supplies to last for days/weeks in case something goes wrong.

I bet the primary point of the touchscreen is the reduced mass of the panel. The Soyuz control panel is heavier and bigger. I think it would also reduce the possibility of a fire and the crew and life support components has a bigger space. The PTK NP capsule design is aiming for similar solutions too.

lighter, you have multiple screens who can be used for the same if needed so no huge issue if one breaks.

Downside is that they are slower to use for time sensitive operations, in space that is emergencies.

Very possible. I would imagine they want to make sure 7 people have enough supplies to last for days/weeks in case something goes wrong.

If something goes wrong, they deorbit and land wherever is practical.

If something goes wrong, they deorbit and land wherever is practical.

Actually not a terribly impractical idea given that the entire launch system is supposed to be reusable. Something goes wrong after launch, you just head back home and refuel, stick everyone on another Dragon V2 and launch again. Sure, you lose fuel, but you needn't actually plan for loooooong stays in space that way.

Touch screen displays are good enhancements of MDF's (good for quick selection or switching between instruments instead using keys around the screen), but obviously they don't use touch screen nor MFD keys and knobs to navigate trough interface or data entry ,but use keys and knobs on hand controllers (F-35 mentioned above is a good example of that) and other areas easy to reach by pilot rather than reaching to instrument panel what can be very tricky... in soyuz they can't even reach instrument panel during launch and they used glorified stick to press the buttons.

Other question is how much control over mission crew would had at all and if they aren't just another payload.

Anyway, I guess that it's too early to talk about dragon interior as they show only bare metal pressure vessel with mock-up seats and panel so it's still long way before we'll see a real thing.
